yeah, that doesn't explain why they started taking away champ names.
and no, it's not unfair in this case because they had the names before any information about the champs were released.

The assumption being that no one has ever had a name that was later given to a champion, resulting in a forced name change.

Given that some of the names of champions are actually quite common, it's reasonable to assume that this isn't the first time it's happened, which means it would be unfair for Riot to *not* follow through on the forced name change in this instance, since the precedent is already heavily established.

As for why it occurs, it's possible that Riot simply doesn't want people to have the same names as champions so other players don't misinterpret it as some kind of direct relationship with Riot (similarly to how players aren't allowed to have "Riot" in their summoner name), the kind of thing that certain players might take advantage of.

That's not how it works.

The system was designed so that a summoner name that uses capitals is the same as a summoner name spelt the same that uses lower case, and all points in between. So "Xayah" will be treated as the *exact same summoner name* as "xayah", as well as "XaYaH", "XAYAH", "xaYAH" etc.

You can easily test this by going to the [Match History](http://matchhistory.oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/#match-history) section of the website, picking a summoner name (preferably someone who's on your friends list so you can more easily see how it works) and then typing (and re-typing) the name into the search box using any combination of upper and lower case letters.
